Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Microfilm to enable enhanced mixing in low-resource diagnostics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to enable smaller diagnostic systems and smaller blood draws without compromising on sample quality and time-to-result. Currently, clinicians who want to ensure that blood samples are well stabilized must use test tubes 1 mL or larger. Meanwhile, point-of-care tests that use smaller volumes are challenged to disperse analytic reagents rapidly and evenly throughout the volume. This project will develop a microfluidic platform for rapid dispersal of dried reagents in whole blood.


This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project tackles a vexing technical challenge. Mixing is hard to achieve in microfluidic systems due to the lack of turbulence. In these so-called low Reynolds number environments, a solute will only move relative to its solvent by diffusion. Depending on the temperature, the size of the solute, and the viscosity of the solvent, mixing across a millimeter-scale chamber can take minutes or even hours. This project will demonstrate a low-power, non-destructive microfluidic mixing technology to rapidly disperse dried reagents into blood. The goal is to accelerate time-to-completion by as much as 10x.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the development of a novel method for mixing in microfluidic systems. Mixing in microfluidic systems is a fundamentally difficult problem, because transport is limited to laminar flow and diffusion. Prior approaches to solving this problem have included channel designs that require high flow rates (and therefore, large working volumes), or adding fine features to the microfluidic chamber itself, which drives up the cost and complexity of diagnostic consumables.

The goal of this project was to show that our actuated, surface-attached post (ASAP) technology could dramatically improve mixing in microfluidic systems. Our goal was a 5x improvement. We demonstrated as much as 50x faster mixing as compared with diffusion alone. The project also involved demonstrating enhancement due to ASAP mixing in a customer-defined assay. In collaboration with a commercial partner, we demonstrated 6x faster hybridization in a microarray assay, and 3-fold higher analyte utilization.

The result of this project will be faster, more sensitive point-of-care diagnostics based on genetic biomarkers. ASAP mixing is new approach to addressing a fundamental challenge in microfluidics, and paves the way for the continued miniaturization and dissemination of low-cost, easy-to-use, powerful diagnostics. More immediately, our collaborative work with potential customers on improving microarray performance has motivated our company to launch a new product line in this space.


Last Modified: 07/18/2016
Modified by: Jay K Fisher

Mixing in microfluidic systems is a fundamentally difficult problem, because transport is limited to laminar flow and diffusion. Prior approaches to solving this problem have included channel designs that require high flow rates (and therefore, large working volumes), or adding fine features to the microfluidic chamber itself, which drives up the cost and complexity of diagnostic consumables. The goal of this project was to show that our actuated, surface-attached post (ASAP) technology could dramatically improve mixing in microfluidic systems. Our goal was a 5x improvement. We demonstrated as much as 50x faster mixing as compared with diffusion alone. The project also involved demonstrating enhancement due to ASAP mixing in a customer-defined assay. In collaboration with a commercial partner, we demonstrated 6x faster hybridization in a microarray assay, and 3-fold higher analyte utilization. The result of this project will be faster, more sensitive point-of-care diagnostics based on genetic biomarkers. ASAP mixing is new approach to addressing a fundamental challenge in microfluidics, and paves the way for the continued miniaturization and dissemination of low-cost, easy-to-use, powerful diagnostics.
